[[File:Versailles chateau.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Palace of Versailles]] (1661–1710)]] The '''Style Louis XIV''', also called French classicism, was the style of architecture and decorative arts intended to glorify [[Louis XIV of France|King Louis XIV]] and his reign. It featured majesty, harmony and regularity. It became the official style during the reign of Louis XIV (1643–1715), imposed upon artists by the newly established ''[[Académie royale de peinture et de sculpture]]'' (Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture) and the ''[[Académie royale d'architecture]]'' (Royal Academy of Architecture). It had an important influence upon the architecture of other European monarchs, from [[Frederick the Great]] of Prussia to [[Peter the Great]] of Russia. Major architects of the period included [[François Mansart]], [[Jules Hardouin Mansart]], [[Robert de Cotte]], [[Pierre Le Muet]], [[Charles Perrault]], and [[Louis Le Vau]]. Major monuments included the [[Palace of Versailles]], the [[Grand Trianon]] at Versailles, and the Church of [[Les Invalides]] (1675–91).
The Louis XIV style had three periods. During the first period, which coincided with the youth of the King (1643-1660) and the regency of [[Anne of Austria]], architecture and art were strongly influenced by the earlier style of [[Louis XIII of France|Louis XIII]] and by the [[Baroque]] style imported from Italy. The early period saw the beginning of French classicism, particularly in the early works of [[Francois Mansart]], such as the [[Chateau de Maisons]] (1630–51). During the second period (1660-1690), under the personal rule of the King, the style of architecture and decoration became more classical, triumphant and ostentatious, expressed in the building of the [[Chateau of Versailles]], first by [[Louis Le Vau]] and then [[Jules Hardouin Mansart|Jules Hardouin-Mansart]].<ref>Ducher, Robert, ''Caractéristique des styles' ' (1988), pg. 120''</ref> Until 1680, furniture was massive, decorated with a profusion of sculpture and gilding. In the later period, thanks to the development of the craft of [[marquetry]], the furniture was decorated with different colors and different woods. The most prominent creator of furniture in the later period was [[André Charles Boulle]].<ref>Renault and Lazé, ''Les Styles de l'architecture et du mobilier'' (2006), Editions Jean-Paul Gisserot, Paris (in French), pg. 54-55.</ref> The final period of Louis XIV style, from about 1690 to 1715, is called the period of transition; it was influenced by Hardouin-Mansart and by the King's designer of fetes and ceremonies, [[Jean Bérain the Elder]]. The new style was lighter in form, and featured greater fantasy and freedom of line, thanks in part to the use of [[wrought iron]] decoration, and greater use of [[arabesque]], [[grotesque]] and coquille designs, which continued into the [[Louis Quinze|style of Louis XV]].{{sfn|Ducher|1988|p. 120}}
==Civil architecture== The model of civic architecture in the early part of the reign was [[Vaux le Vicomte]] (1658), by [[Louis Le Vau]], built for the King's chief of finance [[Nicolas Fouquet]] and completed in 1658. Louis XIV charged Fouquet with theft, put him prison, and took the building for himself. The design was strongly influenced by the classicism of [[François Mansart]]. It combined a facade dominated and rhymed by colossal classical columns, beneath a dome, imported from the [[Italian Baroque architecture]], along with a number of original features, such as a semicircular salon which looked out on the vast [[French formal garden]] created by [[André Le Nôtre]].{{sfn|Ducher|1988|pg. 122}}
Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the [[Grand Trianon]] (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.
Another major new project undertaken by Louis was the construction of a new facade for the east side of the Louvre. Louis invited the most famous sculptor architect of the Italian Baroque, [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]], to submit a design, but rejected it in favor of a more sober and classical colonnade by [[Claude Perrault|Perrault]] (1668). <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Vaux-le-Vicomte Front2.jpg|[[Vaux le Vicomte]] by [[Louis Le Vau]] (1658) File:Louvre Kolonnaden.JPG|The East facade of the [[Louvre]] by [[Louis Le Vau]], [[Charles Le Brun]], [[Francois d'Orbay]] and [[Claude Perrault]] (1667-1678) File:Trianon2.jpg|The [[Grand Trianon]] by [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] (1680-1687) File:Soubise.JPG|Facade of the [[Hotel de Soubise]] by [[Pierre-Alexis Delamair]] (1704–08) </gallery>
==Religious architecture==
In the early period of his reign, Louis began building the church of [[Val-de-Grâce (church)|Val-de-Grâce]] (1645-1710), the chapel of the Val-de-Grace hospital. The design was worked on successively by [[Hardouin Mansart|Mansart]], [[Jacques Lemercier]] and [[Pierre Le Muet]] before being completed by [[Gabriel Leduc]]. Its picturesque tripartite facade, peristyle, detached columns, statues, and ''[[Tondo (art)|tondi]]'', make it the most Italianate and Baroque of Paris churches. It served as the prototype for the later domes of [[Les Invalides]] and the [[Pantheon (Paris)|Pantheon]].{{sfn|Ducher (1988) pg. 124}}
The next major church built under Louis XIV was the church of [[Les Invalides]] (1680-1706). The nave of the church, by [[Libéral Bruant]], was comparable to those of other churches of the period, with ionic pilasters and penetratining vaults, and an interior that resembled the high baroque style. The dome, by Hardouin-Mansart, was more revolutionary, sitting upon a structure with the plan of a [[Greek Cross]]. The design used superimposed orders of columns, in the classical style, but the dome achieved greater height, by resting on a double ''tambour''or drum, and the facade and dome itself were richly decorated with sculptures, ''entablements'' in niches, and ornaments of gilded bronze alternating with the ''nervures'', or ribs of the dome.{{sfn|Ducher (1988) pg. 124}}
The finest church interior of the late Louis XIV period is the chapel of the [[Chateau of Versailles]], created between 1697 and 1710 by [[Hardouin Mansart|Hardouin-Mansart]] and his successor as court architect, [[Robert de Cotte]]. The decor was carefully restrained, with light colors and sculptural detail in slight relief on the columns. The interior of the chapel opened up and lightened by the use of classical columns placed on the tribune, one level above the ground floor, to support the weight of the vaulted ceiling.{{Sfn|Ducher|1988|page=124}} <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Paris, Val de Grâce 03.jpg|[[Val-de-Grâce (church)|Church of Val de Grace]] by [[Louis Le Vau]](1645-1710) File:Église Saint-Roch @ Paris (31685084012).jpg|[[Eglise Saint-Roch]], Paris by [[Jacques Lemercier]] (1653–90) File:Invalides 2007 03 11.jpg|[[Les Invalides]] by [[Hardouin Mansart]] (1680-1706) File:Versailles Chapel - July 2006 edit.jpg|Chapel of the Palace of Versailles by [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] and [[Robert de Cotte]] (1689-1710) </gallery>
== The Grand Style: Paris == Though Louis XIV was later accused of having ignored Paris, his reign saw several massive architectural projects which opened up space and ornamented the center of the city. The idea of monumental urban squares surrounded by uniform architecture had begun in Italy, like many architectural ideas of Baroque period. The first such square in Paris was the Place Royal (now [[Place des Vosges]]) begun by [[Henry IV of France]], completed with an equestrian statue of Louis XIII; then the [[Place Dauphine]] on the [[Ile de la Cité]], which featured an equestrian statue of Henry IV. The initial grand Paris projects of Louis XIV were new facades on the Louvre, one facing the Seine, the other facing to the east. These were showcases of the new monumental style of Louis XIV. The old brick and stone of the Henry IV squares was replaced by the Grand Style of monumental columns, which usually were part of the facade itself, rather than standing separately. All the buildings around the square were connected and built to the same height, in the same style. The ground floor featured a covered arcade for pedestrians.<ref>Texier, Simon (2012), pp. 38-39</ref>
The first such complex of buildings built under Louis XIV was the [[Collège des Quatre-Nations]] (now the [[Institut de France]]) (1662–68), facing the Louvre. It was designed by [[Louis Le Vau]] and [[François d'Orbay]], and combined the headquarters of the academies founded by the King, a chapel, and the library of [[Cardinal Mazarin]]. The [[Les Invalides|Hôtel Royal des Invalides]] - a complex for war veterans consisting of residences, a hospital, and a chapel - was constructed by [[Libéral Bruant]] and [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] (1671-1679). Louis XIV then commissioned Mansart to construct a separate private royal chapel featuring a striking dome, the Église du Dôme, which was added to complete the complex in 1708.
The next major project was the [[Place des Victoires]] (1684-1697), a real estate development of seven large buildings in three segments around an oval square, with an equestrian statue of Louis XIV planned for the centerpiece. This was built by an enterprising entrepreneur and nobleman of the court, Jean-Baptiste Prédot, combined with the architect Jules Haroudin-Mansart. The final urban project became the best-known, the [[Place Vendôme]], also by Harouin-Mansart, between 1699 and 1702. In another innovation, this project was partially financed by the sale of lots around the square. All of these projects featured monumental facades in the Louis XIV style, giving a particular harmony to the squares.<ref>Texier, Simon (2012), pp. 38-39.</ref> <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Institut France Paris 13.jpg|[[Institut de France]] by [[Louis Le Vau]] and [[François d'Orbay]] (1662-1668) File:Place des Victoires, Paris 20 August 2015.jpg|[[Place des Victoires]] (1684-1697) by [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] File:Place Vendôme, Paris August 11, 2011.jpg|[[Place Vendôme]] (1699-1702) by [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]] File:Cour d'honneur des Invalides, Paris April 2011 002.jpg|Court of Honor of [[Les Invalides]] (1671-1706) </gallery>
==Interior decoration== In the early Louis XIV style, the principle characteristics of decor were a richness of materials and an effort to achieve a monumental effect. The materials used included marble, often combined with multicolor stones, bronze, paintings, and mirrors. These were inserted into an extremely framework of columns, pilasters, niches, which extended up the walls and up upon the ceiling. The doors were surrounded with medallions, frontons and bas-reliefs. The chimneys were smaller than those during the Louis XIII era, but more ornate, with a marble shelf supporting vases, below a carved frame with a painting or mirrors, all surrounded by a thick border of carved leaves or flowers.
Decrative elements on the walls of the early Louis XIV style were usually intended to celebrate the military success, majesty and cultural achievements of the King. They often featured military trophies, with helmets, oak leaves symbolizing victory, and masses of weapons, usually made of glided bronze or sculpted wood, in relief surrounded by marble. Other decorative elements celebrated the King personally: the head of the King was often represented as the sun god [[Apollo]], surrounded by palm leaves or gilded rays of light. An eagle usually represented [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]]. Other ornamental details included gilded numbers, royal batons, and crowns.
The [[Hall of Mirrors]] of the Palace of Versailles (1678-1684) was the summit of the early Louis XIV style. Designed by [[Charles Le Brun]], it combined a richness of materials (marble, gold, and bronze) which reflected in the mirrors.
In the late Louis XIV period, after 1690, new elements began to appear, that were less militaristic and more fantastic; particularly seashells, surrounded by elaborate sinuous lines and curves; and exotic designs, including [[arabesques]] and [[Chinoiserie]].{{Sfn|Ducher|1988|pages 126-129}}
<gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Salon de Vénus.jpg|Early Louis XIV style; the Salon de Vénus at the Palace of Versailles by [[Charles Le Brun]] File:Chateau Versailles Galerie des Glaces.jpg|Hall of Mirrors at [[Palace of Versailles]] by [[Charles Le Brun]] (1678-1684) File:Versailles Queen's Chamber.jpg|Bedchamber of the Queen, Palace of Versailles File:Wersal 2013 (22).JPG|Later Louis XIV style; mosaics in the salon of the Oeil-de-Boeuf at Versailles </gallery>
==Furniture== {{Main|Louis XIV furniture}} During the first period of the reign of Louis XIV, furniture followed the previous style of Louis XIII, and was massive, and profusely decorated with sculpture and gilding. After 1680, thanks in large part to the furniture designer [[André Charles Boulle]], a more original and delicate style appeared. It was based on the inlay of [[ebony]] and other rare woods, a technique first used in Florence in the 15th century, which was refined and developed by Boulle and others working for Louis XIV. Furniture was inlaid with plaques of ebony, copper, and exotic woods of different colors.<ref>Renault and Lazé, ''Les Styles de l'architecture et du mobilier'' (2006), pg. 59</ref>
New and often enduring types of furniture appeared; the [[commode]], with two to four drawers, replaced the old ''coffre'', or chest. The ''canapé'', or sofa, appeared, in the form of a combination of two or three armchairs. New kinds of armchairs appeared, including the ''fauteuil en confessionale'' or "Confessional armchair", which had padded cushions ions on either side of the back of the chair. The console table also made its first appearance; it was designed to be placed against a wall. Another new type of furniture was the ''table à gibier'', a marble-topped table for holding dishes. Early varieties of the desk appeared; the [[Bureau Mazarin|Mazarin desk]] had a central section set back, placed between two columns of drawers, with four feet on each column.<ref>Renault and Lazé, ''Les Styles de l'architecture et du mobilier'' (2006), pg. 59</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:André-Charles Boulle, Commode Mazarin (Mazarin Cabinet), 1708, Grand Trianon.jpg|Commode by [[André Charles Boulle]] for the [[Grand Trianon]] (1710) File:Cabinet-Mazarin - Epoque-Louis-XIV.JPG|Early [[Bureau Mazarin|Mazarin desk]] File:0 Grand bureau de Nicolas Fouquet - Château de Vaux-le-Vicomte.JPG|Desk of [[Nicolas Fouquet]] at the Chateau of [[Vaux-le-Vicomte]] File:Un canapé et quatre fauteuils "à la reine" (OA 1280).jpg|Sofa and chairs "a la reine" (1710–20), Louvre Museum </gallery>
==Painting==
In the first part of the reign, French painters were largely influenced by the Italians, particularly [[Caravaggio]]. Notable French painters included [[Nicolas Poussin]], who was living in Rome; [[Claude Lorrain]], who specialized in landscapes and spent most of his career in Rome; [[Louis Le Nain]], who, along with his brothers, did mostly genre works; [[Eustache Le Sueur]], and [[Charles Le Brun]], who studied with Poussin in Rome and were influenced by him.
With the death in 1661 of [[Cardinal Mazarin]], the King's prime minister, Louis decided to take personal charge of all aspects of government, including the arts. His chief advisor on the arts was [[Jean Colbert]] (1619-1683), who was also his finance minister. In 1663 Colbert reorganized the Royal furniture workshops, which made a wide variety of luxury goods, and added to it the [[Gobelins Manufactory|Gobelins tapestry workshops]]. At the same time, with the assistance of Le Brun, Colbert took charge of the [[Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture]], which had been founded by Cardinal Mazarin. Colbert also took a dominant role in architecture, taking the title of Superintendent of buildings in 1664. In 1666, the French Academy in Rome was founded, to take advantage of Rome's position as the leading art center of Europe, and to assure a stream of well-trained painters. Le Brun became the dean of French painters under Louis XIV, involved in architectural projects and interior design. His notable decorative works included the ceiling of the [[Hall of Mirrors]] in the Palace of Versailles.{{Sfn|Bauer and Prater|2016|Page=16}}
The major painters of the later reign of Louis XIV included [[Hyacinthe Rigaud]] (1659-1743) who came to Paris in 1681, and attracted the attention of LeBrun. LeBrun oriented him toward portrait painting, and he made a celebrated portrait of Louis XIV in 1701, surrounded by all the attributes of power, from the crown on the table to the red heels of his shoes. Rigaud soon had an elaborate workshop in place for making portraits of the nobility; he employed specialized artists to create the costumes and draperies, and others to paint the backgrounds, ranging from battlefields to gardens to salons, while he concentrated on the composition, colors and especially the faces.{{Sfn|Bauer and Prater|2016|Page=16}}
[[George de la Tour]] (1593-1652) was another important figure in the Louis XIV style; he was given a title, named court painter of the King, and received high payments for his portraits, though he rarely ever came to Paris, preferring to work in his home town of [[Lunéville]]. His paintings, with their unusual light and dark effecs, were unusually somber, the figures barely seen in the darkness, lit by torchlight, evoking meditation and pity. In addition to religious scenes, he did genre paintings, including the famous ''Tricheur'' or card cheat, showing a young noble being cheated at cards while others look on passively. The writer and later French culture minister [[Andre Malraux]] wrote in 1951, "No other painter, not even Rembrandt, ever suggested such a vast and mysterious silence. La Tour is the only interpreter of the serene aspect of shadows."<ref>cited in Bauer and Prater, ''Baroque'', (2016) page 86.</ref>
In his final years, Louis XIV's tastes changed again, under the influence of his morganic wife, [[Madame de Maintenon]], toward more religious and meditative themes. He had all the paintings in his private room removed and replaced by a single canvas, ''Saint Sebastien being tended by Saint Irene'' (c. 1649) by Georges de la Tour.{{Sfn|Bauer and Prater|2016|Page=86}} <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:Georges de La Tour 003.jpg|''Saint Sebastian tended by Saint Irene'' by [[George de la Tour]] (1649) File:Georges de La Tour - The Cheat with the Ace of Clubs - Google Art Project.jpg|"The Cheat with the Ace of Clubs" by [[Georges de la Tour]] (late 1620s) File:Charles Le Brun - Prise de la ville et de la citadelle de Gand en six jours, 1678 - Google Art Project.jpg|Section of the ceiling of the Hall of Mirrors in Versailles, representing capture of fortress of Ghent by Louis XIV, by [[Charles Le Brun]] (1678) File:Hyacinthe Rigaud - Louis XIV, roi de France (1638-1715) - Google Art Project.jpg|Portrait of Louis XIV by [[Hyacinthe Rigaud]], (1701) </gallery>
==Sculpture== The most influential sculptor of the period was the Italian [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]], whose work in Rome inspired sculptors all over Europe. He traveled to France; his proposal for a new facade of the Louvre was rejected by the King, who wanted a more specifically French style, but the Bernini did make a bust of Louis XIV in 1665 which was greatly admired and imitated in France.
One of the most prominent sculptors under Louis XIV was [[Antoine Coysevox]] (pronounced "qualzevo") (1640-1720) from Lyon. He studied sculpture under [[Louis Lerambert]] and copied in marble ancient Roman works, including the [[Venus de Medici]]. In 1776, his bust of the King's official painter [[Charles Le Brun]] won him admission to the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture. He was soon producing monumental sculpture to accompany the new buildings constructed by Louis XIV; he made a Charlemagne for the royal chapel at [[Les Invalides]], and then a large number of statues for the new Park at Versailles and then at the [[Chateau de Marly]]. He originally made the outdoor statues in weather-resistant stucco, then replaced them with marble works when they were finished in 1705. His work of Neptune from Marly is now in the Louvre, and his statues of Pan and a Flora and Dryad are now found in the [[Tuileries Gardens]]. His statue of ''The King's Fame riding Pegasus'' was originally made for the Chateau of Marly. After the Revolution it was moved to the Tuileries Gardens, and is now inside the Louvre. He also made a series of greatly admired portrait sculptures of the leading statesmen and artists of the time; Louis XIV at Versailles, Colbert (for his tomb at the [[Saint-Eustache, Paris|Church of Saint Eustache]]; [[Cardinal Mazarin]] in the [[Collège des Quatre-Nations]] (now the Institut de France) in Paris; the playwright [[Jean Racine]]; the architect [[Vauban]] and the garden designer [[Andre Le Notre]].<ref>''Coysevox, Charles Antoine'', by Hugh Chisholm from Encyclopedia Britannica 11th edition, (1911), pg. 355-56</ref>
[[Jacques Sarazin]] was another notable sculptor working on projects for Louis XIV. He made many statues and decorations for the Palace of Versailles, as well as the [[Caryatids]] for the eastern facade of the Pavilion du Horloge of the Louvre, facing the Cour Carré, which were based both on a study of the original Greek models, and on the work of [[Michelangelo]].
Another notable sculptor of the Style Louis XV was [[Pierre Paul Puget]] (1620-1694), who was a sculptor, painter, engineer and architect. He was born in Marseille, and first sculpted ornaments for ships under construction. He then travelled to Italy, where he worked as an apprentice on the Baroque ceilings of the [[Palazzo Barberini]] and [[Palazzo Pitti]]. He travelled back and forth between Italy and France, painting, sculpting and wood-carving. He made his celebrated statue of [[caryatids]] for the city hall of Toulon in 1665-67, then was employed by [[Nicolas Fouquet]] to make a statue of Hercules for his chateau at [[Vaux-le-Vicomte]]. He continued to live in th south of France, making notable statues of Milo of Croton, Perseus and Andromeda (now in the Louvre).<ref>''Puget, Pierre,'', by Hugh Chisholm from Encyclopedia Britannica 11th edition, (1911), pg. 637</ref>

==Tapestries== In 1662 [[Jean Baptiste Colbert]] purchased the tapestry workshop of a family of Flemish artisans and transformed it into a royal workshop for the manufacture of furniture and tapestries, under the name of [[Gobelins tapestry]]. Colbert placed the workshop under the direction of the royal court painter, [[Charles Le Brun]], who served in that position from 1663 until 1690. The workshop worked closely with the major painters of the court, who produced the designs. After 1697 the enterprise was reorganized, and thereafter was devoted entirely to the production of tapestries for the King.<ref>"Gobelin". Encyclopædia Britannica. Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). Cambridge University Press. p. 165</ref>
The themes and styles of the tapestry were largely similar to the themes in the paintings of the period, celebrating the majesty of the King and triumphal scenes of military victories, mythological and pastoral scenes. While at first they were made only for use of the King and nobility, the factory soon began exporting its products to the other courts of Europe.
The royal Gobelins manufactory had competition from two private enterprises, the [[Beauvais Manufactory]] and the [[Aubusson tapestry]] workshop, which produced works in the same style but with a low-warp process, with slightly lesser quality. [[Jean Bérain the Elder]], the royal draftsman and designer of the King, created a series of grotesque carpets for Aubusson. These tapestries sometimes celebrated contemporary themes, such as a work designed by Aubusson An late 17th to early 18th century tapestry done by the Beauvais Manufactory depicting Chinese astronomers at the Beijing Ancient Observatory using new more accurate instruments brought to them by Europeans (Jesuits) which were installed in 1644.

==Design and spectacle== In the early years of the King's reign, the most important public royal ceremony was the ''[[carrousel]]'', a series of exercises and games on horseback. These events were designed to replace the tournament, which had been banned after 1559 when King [[Henry II of France|Henry II]] was killed in a jousting accident. In the new, less dangerous version, riders usually had to pass their lance through the interior of a ring, or strike mannequins with the heads of Medusa, Moors and Turks. A grand ''carrousel'' was held on June 5–6, 1662 to celebrate the birth of the ''Dauphin'', the son of Louis XIV. It was held on the square separating the Louvre from the Tuileries Palace, which afterwards became known as the Place du Carrousel.{{sfn|Fierro|1996|page=754}}
The ceremonial entry of the King into Paris also became an occasion for festivities. The return of Louis XIV and Queen Marie-Thérèse to Paris after his coronation in 1660 was celebrated by a grand event on a fairground at the gates of the city, where large thrones were constructed for the new monarchs. After the ceremony the site became known as the Place du Trône, or place of the Throne, until it became the [[Place de la Nation]] in 1880.{{sfn|''Dictionnaire historique de Paris''|2013|page=272}}
An office existed in the royal household of Louis XIV called [[Menus-Plaisirs du Roi]], which was responsible the decoration at royal ceremonies and spectacles, including ballets, masques, illuminations, fireworks, theater performances and other entertainments. This office was held from 1674 to 1711 by [[Jean Bérain the Elder]] (1640-1711). He was also designer of the King's bedchamber and offices, and had an enormous influence upon what became known as the Style Louis XIV; his studio was located in the Grand Gallery of the Louvre, along with those of the royal furniture designer [[André Charles Boulle]]. He was particularly responsible for introducing the a modified version of the [[grotesque]] style of ornament, originally created in Italy by Raphael, into French interior design. He used the grotesque stele not only on wall panels, but also on tapestries made by the [[Aubusson tapestry]] workshops. His many varied other designs included the highly-ornate design of transom of the warship ''Soleil Royal'' (1670), named for the King.<ref>Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Bérain, Jean". Encyclopædia Britannica (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press.</ref>
In addition to interior decoration, he designed the costumes and scenery for the royal theaters, including for the opera ''[[Amadis (Lully)|Amadis]]'' by [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] performed at the [[Théâtre du Palais-Royal (rue Saint-Honoré)|Theater of the Palais Royal]] (1684), and for the opera-ballet ''Les Saisons'' by Lully's successor, [[Pascal Colasse]], in 1695.<ref>Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Bérain, Jean". Encyclopædia Britannica (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press.</ref>

==The garden ''à la Française''== One of the most enduring and popular forms of the Style Louis XIV is The ''Jardin à la française'' or [[French formal garden]], a style based on [[symmetry]] and the principle of imposing order on nature. The most famous example is the [[Gardens of Versailles]] designed by [[André Le Nôtre]], which inspired copies all across Europe. The first important garden à la française was the Chateau of [[Vaux-le-Vicomte]], created by [[Nicolas Fouquet]], the superintendent of Finances to Louis XIV, beginning in 1656. Fouquet commissioned [[Louis Le Vau]] to design the chateau, [[Charles Le Brun]] to design statues for the garden, and [[André Le Nôtre]] to create the gardens. For the first time, that garden and the chateau were perfectly integrated. A grand perspective of 1500 meters extended from the foot of the chateau to the statue of the Hercules of Farnese; and the space was filled with parterres of evergreen shrubs in ornamental patterns, bordered by colored sand, and the alleys were decorated at regular intervals by statues, basins, fountains, and carefully sculpted topiaries. "The symmetry attained at Vaux achieved a degee of perfection and unity rarely equalled in the art of classic gardens. The chateau is at the center of this strict spatial organization which symbolizes power and success."<ref>Prevot, ''Histoire des jardins'', pg. 146</ref>
The Gardens of Versailles, created by [[André Le Nôtre]] between 1662 and 1700, were the greatest achievement of the Garden à la francaise. They were the largest gardens in Europe – with an area of 15,000 hectares, and were laid out on an east–west axis followed the course of the sun: the sun rose over the Court of Honor, lit the Marble Court, crossed the Chateau and lit the bedroom of the King, and set at the end of the Grand Canal, reflected in the mirrors of the Hall of Mirrors.<ref>Prevot, ''Histoire des jardins'', pg. 152</ref> In contrast with the grand perspectives, reaching to the horizon, the garden was full of surprises – fountains, small gardens filled with statuary, which provided a more human scale and intimate spaces. The central symbol of the Garden was the sun; the emblem of [[Louis XIV]], illustrated by the statue of [[Apollo]] in the central fountain of the garden. "The views and perspectives, to and from the palace, continued to infinity. The king ruled over nature, recreating in the garden not only his domination of his territories, but over the court and his subjects."<ref>Lucia Impelluso, ''Jardins, potagers et labyrinthes'', pg. 64.</ref> <gallery mode="packed" heights="150"> File:VauxC17engraving.jpg|17th-century engraving of gardens of [[Vaux-le-Vicomte]] File:Versailles Garden.jpg|Gardens of the [[Palace of Versailles]] File:Bassin Apollon.jpg|The "Basin of Apollo" in the Gardens of Versailles File:Orangerie.jpg|''[[Parterre]]s'' of the [[Orangerie]] at the Palace of Versailles. File:Versailles Grand Trianon.jpg|Gardens of the [[Grand Trianon]] at the Palace of Versailles. </gallery>

In the theory of [[cybernetics]], '''teleogenesis''' (from the [[Greek language|Greek]] ''teleos'' = 'purpose' and ''genesis'' = 'creation') is the creation of goal-creating processes.
According to [[Peter Corning]]: "A cybernetic system is by definition a dynamic purposive system; it is 'designed' to pursue or maintain one or more goals or end-states".
Teleogenesis refers from an extension of classical cybernetics, as proposed by [[Norbert Wiener]], Ashby and others in late 1950s.

'''[[Unmanned aerial vehicle]]s (UAVs)''' or '''drones''' have frequently been involved in military operations. Non-military UAVs have often been reported as causing hazards to aircraft, or to people or property on the ground. Safety concerns have been raised due to the potential for an ingested drone to rapidly disable an aircraft engine,<ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/world/canada/canada-drone-plane.html|title=After Drone Hits Plane in Canada, New Fears About Air Safety|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 October 2017|access-date=23 October 2017}}</ref> and several near-misses and verified collisions have involved hobbyist drone operators flying in violation of aviation safety regulations.<ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/><ref name=ID_2018_balloon>{{cite news |last=Tellman |first=Julie |date=28 September 2018 |title=First-ever recorded drone-hot air balloon collision prompts safety conversation |url=https://www.postregister.com/news/local/first-ever-recorded-drone-hot-air-balloon-collision-prompts-safety/article_7cc41c24-6025-5aa6-b6dd-6d1ea5e85961.html |work=Teton Valley News |publisher=Boise Post-Register |location=Boise, Idaho, United States |access-date=3 October 2018 }}</ref>

However, it is not clear how Iran brought it down.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran says it's almost done decoding US drone |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/45632055/#.Tum-mlaUcg4 |work=MSNBC |date=15 December 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> There have also been claims that Iran spoofed the GPS signal used by the UAV<ref name = NatGeo>Horgen, John (March 2013) [http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/03/unmanned-flight/horgan-text Unmanned Flight] National Geographic, Retrieved 20 February 2013</ref> and hijacked it into landing on an Iranian runway.
==Verified aircraft collisions== ;21 September 2017: A UAV collided with a [[Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk|Black Hawk]] helicopter in the evening over the eastern shore of [[Staten Island]], [[New York City]], [[United States]].<ref name=cbs-new-york-drone-hits-army-helicopter>{{cite news|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/09/22/drone-hits-army-helicopter/|title=Drone Hits Army Helicopter Flying Over Staten Island|publisher=[[WCBS-TV]]|date=22 September 2017|access-date=26 September 2017}}</ref> The helicopter was one of two with the [[82nd Airborne Division]] flying out of [[Fort Bragg]] on duty for the [[United Nations General Assembly]].<ref name=cbs-new-york-drone-hits-army-helicopter/> The helicopters were able to continue flying and landed at [[Linden Airport]].<ref name=cbs-new-york-drone-hits-army-helicopter/> Nobody was hurt, but part of the UAV was found at the bottom of the main rotor system.<ref name=cbs-new-york-drone-hits-army-helicopter/>
:In December 2017 the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] issued an accident report into the collision, finding the pilot of the UAV at fault.<ref name=forbes-ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/johngoglia/2017/12/14/ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision-with-army-helicopter/#22b9b11f7b3f|title=NTSB Finds Drone Pilot At Fault For Midair Collision With Army Helicopter|publisher=[[Forbes]]|last=Goglia|first=John|date=14 December 2017|accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> The UAV operator deliberately flew the UAV 2.5 miles away from himsef and was unaware of the helicopters' presence.<ref name=forbes-ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision/> The operator did not know of the collision until contacted by the NTSB and when interviewed by them showed only a general cursory awareness of the regulations.<ref name=forbes-ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision/> There was also a [[Temporary flight restriction]] in place, which allowed the Black Hawk but not the UAV.<ref name=forbes-ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision/> UAVs are prohibited from flying beyond line of sight under FAA regulations.<ref name=forbes-ntsb-finds-drone-pilot-at-fault-for-midair-collision/>
;12 October 2017: A [[Beechcraft King Air|Beech King Air A100]] of [[Skyjet Aviation]] collided with a [[UAV]] as the former was approaching [[Québec City Jean Lesage International Airport|Jean Lesage Airport]] near [[Quebec City]], [[Canada]].<ref name=bbc-drone-collides-with-commercial-aeroplane-in-canada>{{cite new|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-41635518|title=Drone collides with commercial aeroplane in Canada|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=16 October 2017|access-date=23 October 2017}}</ref><ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/><ref name=cbcnews-garneau-airport-drone-quebec>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/garneau-airport-drone-quebec-1.4355792|title=A first in Canada: Drone collides with passenger plane above Quebec City airport|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=15 October 2017|access-date=23 October 2017}}</ref> The aircraft landed safely despite being hit on the wing.<ref name=bbc-drone-collides-with-commercial-aeroplane-in-canada/><ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/><ref name=cbcnews-garneau-airport-drone-quebec/> Thei aircraft had flown from [[Rouyn-Noranda Airport]] to Rouyn-Noranda Airport with six passengers and two crew.<ref name=bbc-drone-collides-with-commercial-aeroplane-in-canada/><ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/><ref name=cbcnews-garneau-airport-drone-quebec/> A spokeswoman for [[Service de police de la Ville de Québec|Quebec City Police]] said that neither the UAV or operator had been found.<ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/> It had been flying at 1500 feet - five times the maximum altitude that UAVs are permitted to fly in Canada.<ref name=nyt-canada-drone-plane/> Regulations banning flying of UAVs near airports had been introduced earlier in 2017.<ref name=bbc-drone-collides-with-commercial-aeroplane-in-canada/> [[Minister of Transport (Canada)|Minister of Transport]] [[Marc Garneau]] released a statement saying "Although the vast majority of drone operators fly responsibly, it was our concern for incidents like this that prompted me to take action and issue interim safety measures restricting where recreational drones could be flown. I would like to remind drone operators that endangering the safety of an aircraft is extremely dangerous and a serious offence."<ref name=bbc-drone-collides-with-commercial-aeroplane-in-canada/>
;10 August 2018: A [[hot air balloon]] carrying a certified pilot and two passengers was struck by a drone while flying near the Teton County Fairgrounds in [[Driggs, Idaho]], United States. The drone fell to earth and was destroyed after its [[Helicopter rotor|rotors]] were sheared off by contact with the balloon's envelope and load lines; the balloon suffered no significant damage and landed safely with no injuries to the pilot or passengers. The inexperienced hobbyist drone operator reportedly lost sight of the balloon in the aircraft's monitor and was operating within 5 mi (8 km) of [[Driggs–Reed Memorial Airport]] without notifying [[air traffic control]], a violation of [[Federal Aviation Regulations]]; the balloon pilot had relied on radio communication with nearby manned aircraft and air traffic control to avoid other air traffic. The balloon pilot chose to report the incident to the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] in lieu of notifying the local sheriff's department, stating that she "[hopes] this incident helps create a conversation of respect for nature, the airspace, and rules and regulations.” The incident is currently under investigation. This is the first-ever recorded [[mid-air collision]] between a UAV and a hot air balloon.<ref name=ID_2018_balloon/>
==Alleged aircraft collisions== ;17 April 2016: The pilot of [[British Airways]] flight BA727 reported a collision with a UAV to [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]].<ref name=guardian-drone-plane-heathrow>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/17/drone-plane-heathrow-airport-british-airways|title=Drone hits plane at Heathrow airport, says pilot|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|last=Rawlinson|first=Kevin|date=17 April 2016|access-date=17 April 2016}}</ref><ref name=drone-british-airways-collision>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-36067591|title=Drone hits British Airways plane approaching Heathrow Airport|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=17 April 2016|access-date=17 April 2016}}</ref> The [[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A320]] was approaching [[Heathrow Airport]] when the collision happened.<ref name=guardian-drone-plane-heathrow/><ref name=drone-british-airways-collision/> None of the 132 passengers or 5 crew were injured.<ref name=guardian-drone-plane-heathrow/><ref name=drone-british-airways-collision/> After an inspection by engineers, the aircraft was cleared to take off for its next flight.<ref name=guardian-drone-plane-heathrow/><ref name=drone-british-airways-collision/>
:Members of the British government as well as the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and [[British Airline Pilots' Association|BALPA]] called for urgent action, including a register of drone users and geo-fencing of airports.<ref name=guardian-drones-labour-ba-rules-heathrow>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/18/drones-government-labour-ba-rules-drones-heathrow-incident|title=Government vows to tighten rules on drones after Heathrow incident|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=18 Apr 2016|access-date=12 Jul 2016|first=Gwyn|last=Topham}}</ref>
:In late April 2016 [[Secretary of State for Transport|Transport Secretary]] [[Patrick McLoughlin]] told [[Member of parliament#United Kingdom|MPs]] that experts believed that the incident was not related to UAVs.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-ba-plane-strike-not-a-drone-incident>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/28/heathrow-ba-plane-strike-not-a-drone-incident|title=Heathrow plane strike 'not a drone incident'|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 Apr 2016|access-date=12 Jul 2016}}</ref> There was no damage to the aircraft and it wasn't clear if it was a plastic bag rather than a UAV.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-ba-plane-strike-not-a-drone-incident/> An investigation by the [[Air Accidents Investigation Branch]] had been closed due to lack of evidence.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-ba-plane-strike-not-a-drone-incident/> Police had searched a "wide area" of [[Richmond, London|Richmond]] and found nothing.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-ba-plane-strike-not-a-drone-incident/>
==Aircraft near-miss incidents== ===Austria=== ;August 2016: A rescue helicopter carrying a car crash victim to [[Klagenfurt]] hospital had to take evasive action when a UAV flew within metres of.<ref name=the-local-drone-nearly-collides-with-rescue-helicopter>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.at/20160816/drone-nearly-collides-with-rescue-helicopter-in-austria|title=Drone nearly collides with Austrian rescue helicopter|publisher=[[The Local]]|date=16 August 2016|accessdate=21 August 2016}}</ref> Local police were unable to determine who was operating it.<ref name=the-local-drone-nearly-collides-with-rescue-helicopter/>
===[[Canada]]=== ;March 2014:A remote-controlled helicopter was reported by the crew of a [[Boeing 777]] flying 30 metres from their craft at [[Vancouver International Airport]].<ref name=ctv-drone-flight-near-vancouver-airport-attracts-transport-canada-rcmp-attention/>
;April 2014:Video taken from a camera on board a UAV showed the UAV flying close to an airliner as it landed at the same airport.<ref name=ctv-drone-flight-near-vancouver-airport-attracts-transport-canada-rcmp-attention>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/drone-flight-near-vancouver-airport-attracts-transport-canada-rcmp-attention-1.1788494|title=Drone flight near Vancouver airport attracts Transport Canada, RCMP attention|publisher=[[CTV News]]|last=Elliot|first=Jost|date=23 April 2014|accessdate=27 April 2014}}</ref> A [[Transport Canada]] spokesman said his department and the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police|RCMP]] were investigating.<ref name=ctv-drone-flight-near-vancouver-airport-attracts-transport-canada-rcmp-attention/>
;July 2016:[[Edmonton]] police helicopter Air 1 was responding to a call downtown when the pilot saw a white quadcopter with red lights approaching.<ref name=globalnews-ca-near-miss-between-drone-and-eps-helicopter-could-have-been-catastropic>{{cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2867335/near-miss-between-drone-and-eps-helicopter-could-have-been-catastrophic-police-warn/|title=Near miss between drone and EPS helicopter ‘could have been catastrophic,’ police warn|publisher=globalnews.ca|date=5 August 2016|accessdate=21 August 2016|first=Emily|last=Mertz}}</ref> A flight crew member said that a collision "could have been catastrophic and potentially fatal for both crew members of Air 1".<ref name=globalnews-ca-near-miss-between-drone-and-eps-helicopter-could-have-been-catastropic/> [[Transport Canada]] had been made aware of the incident and [[Edmonton Police Service]] said there was a criminal investigation into the events as well as possible charges under the Aeronautics Act.<ref name=globalnews-ca-near-miss-between-drone-and-eps-helicopter-could-have-been-catastropic/>
===China=== In January 2017 a 23 year old UAV operator from [[Xiaoshan District|Xiaoshan]] was detained because of footage taken from a drone flying near airliners descending to land at [[Hangzhou Xiaoshan International Airport]].<ref name=cnn-china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/17/asia/china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss/|title=Drone's operator detained for flying near Chinese airplane|last1=McKirdy|first1=Euan|last2=Wang|first2=Serenitie|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=17 January 2017|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> The incident came to light when footage was uploaded to [[Tencent QQ|QQ]].<ref name=cnn-china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss/> This was an eight-second clip from a ten-minute recording taken from an altitude of 450m.<ref name=cnn-china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss/> The operator had flown it to photograph a sunset, but had also recorded several airliners flying past.<ref name=cnn-china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss/> The model used was a [[Mavic (UAV)|DJI Mavic]] and the manufacturer strongly condemned the incident.<ref name=cnn-china-drone-passenger-plane-near-miss/>
===France=== ;February 2016: A UAV came within 5m of an [[Air France]] [[Airbus A320 family|A320]] flight from [[Barcelona]] to [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]].<ref name=bloomberg-drone-charles-de-gaulle>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-04/drone-brushes-past-airbus-jet-above-paris-in-closest-shave-yet|title=Drone Buzzes Air France Jet Over Paris in Closest Shave Yet|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|last1=Rothman|first1=Andrea|last2=Fouquet|first2=Helene|date=4 March 2016|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> The aircraft was at an altitude of 1600m when the pilot saw the UAV to the planes' port, disengaged the autopilot and took evasive action.<ref name=bloomberg-drone-charles-de-gaulle/> The [[Bureau d'Enquêtes et d'Analyses pour la Sécurité de l'Aviation Civile]] has initiated the first French inquiry into a near miss involving a UAV.<ref name=bloomberg-drone-charles-de-gaulle/>
===New Zealand=== ;March 2018: A UAV came within 5m of an [[Air New Zealand]] [[Boeing 777-200]] on [[Final approach (aeronautics)|final approach]] to [[Auckland Airport]] on 25 March 2018.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/amp/world-asia-43551373|title=Air New Zealand calls for drone legislation after near miss|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=27 March 2018|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref> The pilots spotted the UAV as the aircraft was at a point in its' descent where it was not possible to take evasive action and they initially feared it would be sucked into an engine.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss/> Flight NZ92, which flew from Tokyo to Auckland, was unharmed.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss/> The identity of the UAV controller is unknown.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss/> Air New Zealand called for tougher laws to prevent reckless use of UAVs near airports and prison terms for operators who endanger lives.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss/> Under current laws operators who breach Civil Aviation Rules can be fined up to NZ$5000.<ref name=bbc-news-air-new-zealand-calls-for-drone-legislation-after-near-miss/>
===Poland=== ;21 July 2015: A [[Lufthansa]] plane landing at [[Warsaw Chopin Airport]] nearly collided with a drone. The drone came in within 100 m of the plane, at an altitude of 760 m, 5 km away from the airport, near [[Piaseczno]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33605869 |title=Lufthansa plane in near miss with drone on Warsaw approach |date=21 July 2015 |accessdate=23 July 2015 |publisher=BBC News |location=Europe }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/lufthansa-plane-drone_55ae6c98e4b07af29d5668f7 |title=Lufthansa Plane Almost Hits Mystery Drone Midflight |date=21 July 2015 |accessdate=23 July 2015 |publisher=Huffington Post |agency=AP |location=Warsaw, Poland}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/lufthansa-plane-nearly-collides-with-drone-in-poland/a-18598624 |title=Lufthansa plane nearly collides with drone in Poland |date=21 July 2015 |accessdate=23 July 2015 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |agency=AP, Reuters}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== ;October 2014:It was reported that a UAV had flown within 25 metres of an [[ATR 72]] passenger airliner on 30 May 2014.<ref name=the-independent-quadcopter-drone-deliberately-flown>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/quadcopter-drone-deliberately-flown-at-uk-passenger-plane-came-too-close-9820880.html|title=Quadcopter drone flew 'deliberately close' to UK passenger plane|date=27 October 2014|accessdate=2 November 2014|publisher=[[The Independent]]|last=Vincent|first=James|location=London}}</ref><ref name=bbc-southend-uav>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-essex-29785322|title=Quadcopter drone flew 'too close' to Southend-bound plane|date=27 October 2014|accessdate=2 November 2014|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref><ref name=airprox-southend-report>{{cite web|url=http://www.airproxboard.org.uk/docs/423/2014073%20-%20v2.pdf|title=AIRPROX REPORT No 2014073|publisher=Airproxboard.org.uk|accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> The aircraft was approaching [[London Southend Airport]] and about to intercept the [[Instrument landing system|ILS]] glide slope when the copilot reported seeing a small craft flying about 100 m to the right of the aircraft.<ref name=the-independent-quadcopter-drone-deliberately-flown/><ref name=bbc-southend-uav/><ref name=airprox-southend-report/> The copilot and Air Traffic Controller agreed it was probably a quadcopter – it was seen flying as close as 25 m to the aircraft.<ref name=the-independent-quadcopter-drone-deliberately-flown/><ref name=bbc-southend-uav/><ref name=airprox-southend-report/> Southend ATC couldn't detect the craft on radar – subsequent examination of radar from other sites produced several brief but inconclusive radar signals.<ref name=airprox-southend-report/> Police were contacted, but the operator of the UAV could not be found.<ref name=the-independent-quadcopter-drone-deliberately-flown/><ref name=bbc-southend-uav/><ref name=airprox-southend-report/>
;December 2014:Investigators confirmed that they were investigating claims that a UAV came about 20 feet of an [[Airbus A320 family#A320|Airbus A320]] landing at [[London Heathrow Airport|Heathrow]] on 22 July.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-plane-near-miss-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/12/heathrow-plane-near-miss-drone|title=Investigators confirm Heathrow plane in near miss with drone|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=12 December 2014}}</ref> The A320 was 700 feet from landing when the craft passed 20 feet over the left wing of the aircraft – they did not collide.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-plane-near-miss-drone/> Despite an investigation and cooperation of remote-control model aircraft club members, the operator of the aircraft could not be identified.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-plane-near-miss-drone/> The incident was given an A rating, meaning that there had been a serious risk of collision.<ref name=guardian-heathrow-plane-near-miss-drone/>
;April 2015:A [[Westland Lynx]] flying over [[Hambrook]] had to take evasive action to avoid a UAV that passed one rotor span from the side of the helicopter.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/mar/02/pilots-research-impact-drone-hitting-passenger-jet?CMP=twt_gu|title=Pilots call for research into impact of drone hitting passenger jet|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=2 March 2016|accessdate=2 March 2016}}</ref>
;June 2015:An autogyro flying over [[Detling]], [[Kent]] encountered a UAV at an altitude of 450 metres.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/> The UAV was 20m from the autogyro and the pilot considered the risk of collision high.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;July 2015:Both crew members of an RJ1 saw a UAV at an altitude of 1200m over Detling, Kent.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/> As it would not be visible from the ground, the United Kingdom Airprox Board concluded that it was impossible for it to be flown legally under those circumstances.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;July 2015:A BE200 aircraft approaching [[Southampton Airport]] when a UAV passed within two wing lengths of it.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/> Investigators concluded that chance played a large role in the vehicles not colliding.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;July 2015:A [[Dornier 328]] was on final approach to [[Manchester Airport]] at 850m when a blue UAV was spotted.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/> Investigators concluded that the UAV was not permitted to be in that space.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;September 2015:A [[Boeing 737]] had a [[Near miss (safety)|near miss]] shortly after takeoff from [[London Stansted Airport]], leaving the pilot no time to react.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;September 2015:A UAV came within 20m of an [[Embraer 170]] over the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] as the latter aircraft was on approach to [[London City Airport]].<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;September 2015:Shortly after a [[Boeing 777]] had taken off from [[Heathrow Airport]], a UAV passed within 25 metres of the jet at the same height.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;September 2015:An Airbus A319 was landing at [[Heathrow Airport]] at 150m when a UAV was seen about 23m to the left and 6m above the airliner.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;October 2015:A [[Dornier 328]] was taking off from [[Manchester Airport]] when a UAV passed 15m from the left wing tip when the latter was at 900m, leading the pilot to conclude there was a high risk of collision.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;October 2015:A [[Piper PA-28 Cherokee]] was flying near Otherton Airfield, Staffordshire, when a UAV passed about 6m from the wing tip.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;March 2016:[[BALPA]] called for tests to determine the possible outcomes of UAVs colliding with passenger aircraft.<ref name=guardian-uk-balpa-call-for-research/>
;August 2016: An [[East Anglian Air Ambulance]] [[Eurocopter EC145]] narrowly avoided a collision with a drone over north London at 7:45PM on August 26.<ref name=guardian-helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/mar/26/helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash|title=Helicopter regularly flown by Prince William escapes drone crash|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=26 March 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> The drone passed within 30m of the air ambulance and was seen by the crew.<ref name=guardian-helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash/> Investigators found there was a high risk of the helicopter and UAV coming into contact, endangering the helicopter.<ref name=guardian-helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash/> The UAV was also being operated over a built-up area without Civil Aerial Authority permission and the incident was classed in the highest risk category, A.<ref name=guardian-helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash/> [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] regularly flies the helicopter but was not on duty at the time of the incident.<ref name=guardian-helicopter-regularly-flown-prince-william-escapes-drone-crash/>
;November 2016: An [[EasyJet]] aircraft landing at Edinburgh Airport narrowly avoided colliding with a UAV flying at the same altitude by 23m.<ref name=bbc-matter-of-luck>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-39748047|title='Matter of luck' that Easyjet plane missed drone|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=28 April 2017|accessdate=2 July 2017}}</ref> The Airprox Board said a collision had only been avoided "by providence".<ref name=bbc-matter-of-luck/>
;May 2017: A [[Loganair]] flight descending into [[Edinburgh Airport]] had to take evasive action when the crew saw a UAV about 20-30m from the aircraft at an altitude of 4,000 feet.<ref name=bbc-edinburgh-airport-drone-loganair>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-40019778|title=Drone in near miss with plane near Edinburgh Airport|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> The flight from [[Shetland]] landed safely.<ref name=bbc-edinburgh-airport-drone-loganair/> Police believe the UAV was operated from [[Bathgate]] or [[Armadale, West Lothian|Armadale]].<ref name=bbc-edinburgh-airport-drone-loganair/>
;July 2017: Gatwick Airport closed its' runway because of a UAV flying nearby.<ref name=bbc-drone-causes-disruption-at-gatwick>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-40476264|title=Drone causes disruption at Gatwick airport|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2 July 2017|accessdate=2 July 2017}}</ref> The runway was closed for one period of nine minutes, then another of five minutes.<ref name=bbc-drone-causes-disruption-at-gatwick/> EasyJet said four of its' flights were diverted and British Airways said one of its' flights had been diverted to [[Bournemouth Airport|Bournemouth]].<ref name=bbc-drone-causes-disruption-at-gatwick/> Sussex Police are investigating.<ref name=bbc-drone-causes-disruption-at-gatwick/>
;9 July 2017: An [[Airbus 319]] was preparing to land when a UAV appeared and flew over the aircraft's starboard wing.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-sussex-41627552|title=Gatwick flight drone near-miss 'put 130 lives at risk'|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=15 Oct 2017|access-date=15 Oct 2017}}</ref> The UAV was initially thought to be a bird, appearing as a small dark object due to twilight conditions at 20:35 BST.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> At the closest point of approach, the drone appeared between the wing tip and fuselage, above the starboard wing.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> The aircraft landed safely and Gatwick Airport police were involved.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> A UK Airprox Board report into the incident said there was a high risk of collision and that "A larger aircraft might not have missed it and in the captain's opinion, it had put 130 lives at risk.".<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> The report also said the UAV was "very large, certainly not a toy", had four blades and estimated that the drone was about three metres across.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> The report said that the estimated distance and pilots' inability to avoid the UAV "portrayed a situation where providence had played a major part" in avoiding an accident.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> Former pilot Stephen Landells said it was a "worrying near-miss that could have ended in tragedy".<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/> Mr Landells also said that BALPA wanted to see details of proposed legislation for drone registration and a timeline for said registration.<ref name=bbc-gatwick-flight-drone-near-miss-put-130-lives-at-risk/>
===United States=== ;March 2013:An [[Alitalia]] pilot on final approach to runway 31 right at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]] reported seeing a small UAV near his aircraft.<ref name=nyt-alitialia-report-drone>{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/05/jetliners-pilot-reports-seeing-drone-near-kennedy-airport/|title=Pilot Says Drone Flew Past Jet Nearing J.F.K.|publisher=The New York Times|last1=McGeehan|first1=Patrick|last2=Goldstein|first2=Joseph|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=wired-Alitalia-report-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/03/ufo-black-drone-fbi/|title=FBI Investigating Unidentified Drone Spotted Near JFK Airport|publisher=[[Wired (website)|Wired]]|last=Kravets|first=David|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=csm-alitalia-report-drone>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2013/0305/Mystery-drone-near-JFK-airport-FBI-seeks-public-s-help-in-investigation-video|title=Mystery drone near JFK airport: FBI seeks public's help in investigation|publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|last=Mulrine|first=Anna|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=latimes-alitalia-report-drone>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/mar/05/nation/la-na-nn-faa-drone-jfk-airport-20130305|title=FAA investigating report of drone aircraft over JFK airport|last=Muskal|first=Michael|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref> Both the FAA and FBI were reported to be investigating.<ref name=nyt-alitialia-report-drone/><ref name=wired-Alitalia-report-drone/><ref name=csm-alitalia-report-drone/><ref name=latimes-alitalia-report-drone/>
;22 March 2014:[[US Airways]] Flight 4650 nearly collided with a drone while landing at [[Tallahassee Regional Airport]]. The plane, a [[Bombardier CRJ200]], was at an altitude of {{convert|2300|ft|m}} when it came dangerously close to the drone, described by one of the pilots "as a camouflaged F-4 fixed-wing aircraft that was quite small". Jim Williams, head of the UAV office at the [[Federal Aviation Administration]], said: "The risk for a small [drone] to be ingested into a passenger airline engine is very real." The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] was investigating the incident, which was the first known instance of a large airliner nearly colliding with a drone in the U.S.<ref name=businessinsider-tallahassee>{{cite web|last=Zhang|first=Benjamin|title=FAA: US Airways Plane Nearly Collided With Drone|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/faa-us-airways-jet-nearly-collided-with-drone-2014-5|work=Business Insider|accessdate=9 May 2014|date=9 May 2014}}</ref> However, the authenticity of this report is under dispute.<ref>http://www.politico.com/story/2014/11/faa-drones-planes-112786</ref>
;5 December 2015:A [[California Highway Patrol]] helicopter in [[Martinez, California]] was working with local police when they spotted the lights of a UAV.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone>{{cite news|url=http://abc7news.com/news/chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone-over-martinez/1112519/|title=CHP helicopter nearly collides with drone over Martinez|publisher=abclocal.go.com|last=Quintana|first=Sergio|date=6 December 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> They were flying between seven and eight hundred feet and the UAV was about the same height.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone/> The helicopter banked to evade it, but the UAV passed by it.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone/> The helicopter followed the UAV to where it landed and called local police to find the operator.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone/> The CHP asked UAV operators to be careful about flying.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone/> The incident has been passed to the [[Federal Aviation Authority]] for investigation.<ref name=abc7news-chp-helicopter-nearly-collides-with-drone/> According to the operator of the UAV, it was flying on autopilot because of a lost radio signal.<ref name=cbslocal-drone-near-miss-chp>{{cite news|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2015/12/17/drone-near-miss-chp-helicopter-martinez-owen-ouyang-apology-autopilot/|title=Pilot Of Drone That Nearly Hit CHP Helicopter Says It Was On Autopilot|publisher=cbslocal.com|date=17 December 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> The operator was cooperating with FAA, police and [[California Department of Transportation|Caltrans]] and has offered an apology to the helicopter pilot.<ref name=cbslocal-drone-near-miss-chp/>
;March 2016: A [[Lufthansa]] [[Airbus A380]] reported a near miss as it approached [[Los Angeles International Airport]].<ref name=lat-lufthansa-drone-near-miss>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-drone-near-miss-lax-20160318-story.html|title=Lufthansa jet and drone nearly collide near LAX|first=Joseph|last=Serna|date=19 March 2016|accessdate=20 March 2016|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> The airliner was at an elevation of 5000 feet and about 14 miles east of the airport when the UAV flew 200 feet over it.<ref name=lat-lufthansa-drone-near-miss/> Police searched for the UAV pilot, though they admitted the search would be a long shot.<ref name=lat-lufthansa-drone-near-miss/>
;2018: A video posted to YouTube showed footage from a UAV in midair above an [[Airbus 320]] in [[Frontier Airlines]] livery.<ref name=atw-industry-condemns-video>{{cite news|url=http://atwonline.com/regulation/industry-condemns-video-drone-close-encounter-frontier-aircraft|title= Industry condemns video of drone close encounter with Frontier aircraft|last=Atherson|first=Kelsey|publisher=[[Air Transport World]]|date=2 February 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=flyingmag-faa-investigating-video>{{cite news|url=https://www.flyingmag.com/faa-investigating-video-drone-flying-dangerously-close-to-airliner|title=FAA Investigating Video of Drone Flying Dangerously Close to Airliner|publisher=flyingmag.com|date=6 February 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> The airport was identified as [[McCarran International Airport]] and the UAV may have taken off from a parking lot near Whitney Mesa Nature Preserve to the east of the airport.<ref name=atw-industry-condemns-video/><ref name=flyingmag-faa-investigating-video/> Both [[Academy of Model Aeronautics|The Academy of Model Aeronautics]] and [[Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International]] condemned the video.<ref name=atw-industry-condemns-video/> The Federal Aviation Authority is investigating the incident.<ref name=atw-industry-condemns-video/><ref name=flyingmag-faa-investigating-video/>
