In addition to anti-aircraft weapons, UAVs are vulnerable to power and communications link losses.<ref name=Malfunction>{{cite news|last1=Whitlock|first1=Craig|title=How crashing drones are exposing secrets about U.S. war operations|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/how-crashing-drones-are-exposing-secrets-about-us-war-operations/2015/03/24/e89ed940-d197-11e4-8fce-3941fc548f1c_story.html|accessdate=22 May 2015|work=Washington Post|date=25 March 2015|quote=Although they malfunction less often than they used to, they still crash at a higher rate than other military aircraft. Of the 269 Predators acquired by the Air Force over the past two decades, more than half have wrecked in major accidents, records show.}}</ref>
===Australia=== <!--Please see note above before adding info to this section --> ;October 2013:A UAV collided with [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]].<ref name=smh-mystery-drone>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/mystery-drone-collides-with-sydney-harbour-bridge-20131004-2uzks.html|title=Mystery drone collides with Sydney Harbour Bridge|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|last=Kontominas|first=Bellinda|date=4 October 2013|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> The [[Civil Aviation Safety Authority]] (CASA) started an investigation.<ref name=smh-mystery-drone/> The police returned the craft to its owner.<ref name=smh-i-dont-know-whether>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/sci-tech/i-dont-know-whether-its-a-bomb-or-not-train-driver-flummoxed-after-drone-hits-sydney-harbour-bridge-20131126-2y76m.html|title='I don't know whether it's a bomb or not': Train driver flummoxed after drone hits Sydney Harbour Bridge|publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|last=Cosier|first=Colin|date=26 November 2013|accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref>
;April 2014:A [[Triathlon|triathlete]] was injured in an incident involving a drone that was filming a race.<ref name=guardian-air-safety-triathlete-struck-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/08/air-safety-triathlete-struck-drone|title=Air safety investigation into drone incident with triathlete|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 April 2014|accessdate=27 April 2014|last=Safi|first=Michael}}</ref> She claimed that the drone collided with her and said "''the ambulance crew took a piece of propeller from my head''".<ref name=guardian-air-safety-triathlete-struck-drone/> The owner of the UAV claimed that the athlete had been injured when she was frightened by the falling UAV and tripped.<ref name=guardian-air-safety-triathlete-struck-drone/> Timing equipment caused interference with the operation of the UAV while it was close to people on the ground.<ref name=smh-drone-operators-referred>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/drone-operators-involved-in-athletes-injury-referred-to-director-of-public-prosecutions-20140708-zszsy.html|title=Drone operators involved in athlete's injury referred to Director of Public Prosecutions|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|last=Grubb|first=Ben|date=8 July 2014|accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref> In November 2014, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions stated that the evidence showed that the drone had crashed into the triathlete who sustained head injuries as a result. However taking into account the young age and antacedents of the drone operator the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions chose not to proceed with a charge against the operator and handed the matter back to CASA. CASA subsequently fined the operator $1,700 for flying the drone within 30 metres of people.<ref name=abc>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-13/drone-operator-at-geraldton-marathon-fined/5887196|title=Drone operator fined after UAV crashed into Geraldton triathlete|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]|date=13 November 2014}}</ref>
;February 2016:A recreational drone pilot crashed their drone, a DJI Phantom, during a ceremony at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra.<ref>http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-19/drone-crashes-in-middle-of-ceremony-at-war-memorial-in-canberra/7185202</ref> No one was injured. The drone reportedly landed near the Memorial's Director, and former defence minister, Brendan Nelson, who picked it up and subsequently handed it to security staff.<ref name="canberratimes.com.au">http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/man-who-crashed-drone-at-australian-war-memorial-fined-900-20160421-gobs8e.html</ref> Following a Civil Aviation and Safety Authority (CASA) investigation the drone pilot was fined $900, which according to a CASA spokesman, closed the matter.<ref name="canberratimes.com.au"/>
===Canada=== ;June 2016:Stephanie Creignou was attending a [[5K run]] in [[Beloeil, Quebec]] when a [[Phantom (UAV)|DJI Phantom 3]] fell and hit her on the head.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone>{{cite news|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/flight/drones/a21519/drone-hits-woman/|title=Woman Hit By Falling Drone at Sporting Event|first=Sophie|last=Weiner|publisher=[[Popular Mechanics]]|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> She was taken to hospital where she was diagnosed with [[Whiplash (medicine)|whiplash]].<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/> As of 22 June she was still out of work and had had to cancel a holiday with her husband.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/> Rosaire Turcotte, who operated the UAV that crashed, said he couldn't understand how it happened and that he'd acted safely.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/> The incident was caught by a camera on a different UAV, one owned by VTOL-X drones, who had been hired to cover the event.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/> Flavio Martenkowski, CEO of VTOL-X, said he's spoken to Turcotte about the danger of flying so near to a crowd just before the crash.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/> The [[Transportation Safety Board of Canada]] has opened an investigation into the crash.<ref name=popular-mechanics-woman-hit-by-falling-drone/>
===France=== ;October 2013:A tourist was arrested in Paris and fined 400 euro for "operating an aircraft non-compliant with safety laws".<ref name=jpost-drone-paris>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Israeli-tourist-fined-and-arrested-for-flying-drone-over-Paris-378056|title=Israeli tourist arrested for flying drone over Paris|date=5 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=jpost-drone-paris/>
;October and November 2014:Unidentified UAVs were seen flying near 13 nuclear power plants.<ref name=nyt-unidentified-drones-above-french-nuclear>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/04/world/europe/unidentified-drones-are-spotted-above-french-nuclear-plants.html?_r=0|title=Unidentified Drones Are Seen Above French Nuclear Plants|date=3 November 2014|accessdate=9 November 2014|last=de la BAUME|first=Maïa|publisher=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The [[Secretariat-General for National Defence and Security (France)|Secretariat-General for National Defence and Security]] issued a statement that the flights were an "organized provocation".<ref name=nyt-unidentified-drones-above-french-nuclear/>
;March 2016:A UAV with a wingspan of 3m went out of control and was pursued by two Belgian [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] fighter aircraft.<ref name=flandersnews-largedrone>{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws.english/News/1.2587685|title=French jets scrambled to follow out-of-control Flemish drone|publisher=flandersnews.be|date=1 March 2016|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref> When it flew into French airspace it was pursued by French [[Dassault Rafale|Rafale]] fighters for two hours until it crashed in a field near [[Dizy-le-Gros]].<ref name=flandersnews-largedrone/> It had been built by the [[Flemish Institute for Technological Research]] and had taken off from [[Weelde Air Base]].<ref name=flandersnews-largedrone/> <!--Please see note above before adding info to this section -->
===India=== ;May 2014: Francescos' Pizza of [[Mumbai]] made a test delivery from a branch in [[Lower Parel]] to the roof of a building in [[Worli]].<ref name=times-of-india-been-there-drone-that>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Been-there-drone-that-Pizza-air-delivery-in-Mumbai/articleshow/35445623.cms|title=Been there, drone that: Pizza air-delivery in Mumbai|publisher=[[The Times of India]]|date=22 May 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014}}</ref> [[Mumbai Police|Police in Mumbai]] began an investigation on the grounds that security clearances had not been sought.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/mumbai-police-seeks-explanation-on-drone-pizza-delivery/article6043644.ece|title=Mumbai police seeks explanation on drone pizza delivery|last=Rajput|first=Rashmi|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|date=24 May 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> <!--Please see note above before adding info to this section -->
===Republic of Ireland=== ;2012:A theatre group flew [[Parrot AR.Drone]]s in Dublin<ref name=siliconrepublic-aerial-assault>{{cite news|title=Aerial assault on Facebook and Google as part of Dublin ‘Hack the City’ attempt (video)|url=http://www.siliconrepublic.com/innovation/item/27888-aerial-assault-on-facebook|date=21 June 2012|accessdate=6 July 2013|publisher=Silicon Republic}}</ref> to film video for an exhibit.<ref name=siliconrepublic-aerial-assault/> The Irish Aviation Authority stated that this was prohibited as Dublin city is classed as a restricted area.<ref name=thejournal-ie-drones-dublin>{{cite news|title=Drone group held under terrorist act at London airport after Dublin show|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/drones-dublin-filming-terrorism-science-gallery-drone-unmanned-legal-licence-496562-Jun2012/|date=22 June 2012|publisher=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
;April 2014: A video of [[Cork (city)|Cork]] taken by Raymond Fogarty became popular online, but was criticised by licensed operators SkyTec.<ref name=it-game-of-drones>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/people/game-of-drones-as-remote-pilots-ignore-the-rules-1.1891523|title=Game of drones as remote pilots ignore the rules|publisher=[[The Irish Times]]|last=Murphy|first=Darragh|date=14 August 2014|accessdate=2 July 2017}}</ref> Fogarty later became a commercial UAV pilot and urged UAV operators to be aware of laws and not fly over build up areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/cork-airport-launches-no-drone-zone-412519.html|title=Cork Airport launches ‘no drone zone’|last=English|first=Eoin|publisher=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=27 July 2016|accessdate=2 July 2017}}</ref> <!--Please see note above before adding info to this section -->
===Italy=== ;December 2015:A UAV filming a slalom event in [[Madonna di Campiglio]] nearly hit [[Marcel Hirscher]].<ref name=denver-post-ski-federation-bans-drones>{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/wintersports/ci_29303076/ski-federation-bans-drones-after-camera-nearly-hits|title=Ski federation bans drones after camera nearly hits Marcel Hirscher|last=Willemsen|first=Eric|publisher=[[The Denver Post]]|date=23 December 2015|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> The [[International Ski Federation]] had agreed to the use of the UAV, though the pilot was not allowed to fly directly over the race course.<ref name=denver-post-ski-federation-bans-drones/> The race director said that the pilot had not followed the federations' instructions.<ref name=denver-post-ski-federation-bans-drones/> Camera UAVs have since been banned from the federations' World Cup races.<ref name=denver-post-ski-federation-bans-drones/>
===South Africa=== ;June 2013:Police officers apprehended a man who flew a multicopter outside the hospital that [[Nelson Mandela]] was in.<ref name=news24-techno-tussle>{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Techno-tussle-at-Mandela-hospital-20130628|title= Techno-tussle at Mandela hospital|date=28 June 2013|accessdate=3 April 2014|publisher=[[News24]]}}</ref> The equipment and footage were confiscated by the police.<ref name=times-za-arrested-cameraman-apologises>{{cite news|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2013/06/29/arrested-cameraman-apologises-for-mandela-drone-journalism|title=Arrested cameraman apologises for Mandela drone journalism|date=29 June 2013|accessdate=3 April 2014|publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)]]}}</ref>
;April 2016:A UAV hit and broke an office window in [[Cape Town]] and collided with David Perel, an interface designer and racing driver for Kessel Ferrari.<ref name=abc-news-drone-crashes-window>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/drone-crashes-window-hits-mans-head/story?id=38253589|title=Drone Crashes Through Window, Hits Man's Head|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Borrello|first=Steve|date=8 April 2016|accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> The operator and a friend went to check that he hadn't been injured and Perel returned the UAV.<ref name=abc-news-drone-crashes-window/> The [[South African Civil Aviation Authority|SACAA]] contacted both Perel and the operators after video of the incident appeared on YouTube.<ref name=abc-news-drone-crashes-window/> <!--Please see note above before adding info to this section -->
===United Kingdom=== ;April 2014:A man pleaded guilty to flying a small UAV within 50 m of a submarine testing facility.<ref name=guardian-uk-first-drone-conviction>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/02/uk-first-drone-conviction|title=UK's first drone conviction will bankrupt me, says Cumbrian man|date=2 April 2014|accessdate=2 April 2014|last=Arthur|first=Charles|publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref name=guardian-uk-first-drone-conviction/> He claimed that he had been flying a mile from the base but had lost radio contact with the craft.<ref name=guardian-uk-first-drone-conviction/> He was fined £800 and ordered to pay [[Costs in English law|legal costs]] of £3,500.<ref name=guardian-uk-first-drone-conviction/> The CAA claimed that the case raised safety issues related to flying unmanned aircraft.<ref name=guardian-uk-first-drone-conviction/>
;September 2015:Nigel Wilson, of Bingham, Nottinghamshire, admitted nine breaches of the Air Navigation Order the previous year.<ref name=bbc-man-fined-after-flying-drones>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-34256680|title=Man fined after flying drones over Premier League stadiums|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> He was fined ₤1,800 and banned from buying or using a UAV for two years.<ref name=bbc-man-fined-after-flying-drones/>
;November 2015:It was reported that a toddler had lost an eye as a result of an accident with a UAV.<ref name=bbc-toddler-injured-by-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-34936739?SThisFB|title=Toddler's eyeball sliced in half by drone propeller|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=26 November 2015|accessdate=26 November 2015}}</ref> Simon Evans flew the UAV which accidentally struck a tree and started spinning before it struck Oscar Webb.<ref name=bbc-toddler-injured-by-drone/> Oscar can see out of his uninjured eye, but will require several operations before fitting a prosthetic eye.<ref name=bbc-toddler-injured-by-drone/> Oscar's family have forgiven Evans, but he hasn't flown any of his UAVs since, saying that when he looks at his UAVs since the incident he feels "physically sick".<ref name=bbc-toddler-injured-by-drone/>
;December 2015:[[Lincolnshire Police]] asked the operator of a UAV to come forward after footage taken by it flying over [[Lincoln, England|Lincoln]] appeared on [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-35036487|title=Lincolnshire Police make 'unusual' drone appeal|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=8 December 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> The flight was criticised by an expert as "incredibly irresponsible".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-35050426|title=Footage shows 'illegal' drone flight over Lincoln|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=11 December 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref>
;March 2016:A UAV collided with a train hauled by the [[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|Flying Scotsman]] [[steam locomotive]].<ref name=telegraph-flying-scotsman>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/road-and-rail-transport/12196992/Flying-Scotsman-hit-by-drone-on-North-York-Moors.html|title=Flying Scotsman hit by drone on North York Moors|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=17 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref> [[British Transport Police]] opened an investigation, having identified the operator, and warned UAV operators not to fly within 50 metres of a train as it is illegal.<ref name=york-press-flying-scotsman>{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/14351263.Drone_hits_Flying_Scotsman_on_North_Yorkshire_Moors/|title=Drone hits Flying Scotsman on North Yorkshire Moors|publisher=[[The Press (York)]]|date=17 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref>
;July 2016:Daniel Kelly, from [[Grove Park, Lewisham]], [[London]] pleaded guilty to using a UAV to send a psychoactive substance and tobacco into [[HM Prison Swaleside|HMP Swaleside]].<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-kent-36849156|title=Man jailed over HMP Swaleside drone deliveries|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=}}</ref> He was arrested on 25 April 2016 in [[Leysdown-on-Sea]].<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone/> Police had spotted a vehicle with the lights on, then someone ran to it and it sped off.<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone/> A UAV was found in the boot of the car – it had been sprayed with black paint and black tape had been put over the lights.<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone/> [[Kent Police]] said it was probably the first UK conviction of its type.<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone/> His girlfriend was cleared of the same charges.<ref name=bbc-man-jailed-over-hmp-swaleside-drone/> He had also flown over [[HM Prison Elmley|HMP Elmley]], [[HM Prison Wandsworth|HMP Wandsworth]] and [[HM Prison The Mount]].<ref name=times-man-jailed-for-flying-drugs-into-prisons>{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/man-jailed-for-flying-drugs-into-prisons-using-drone-j0prlj0n6|title=Man jailed for flying drugs into prisons using drone|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=22 July 2016|accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref>
=== United States === ;August 1956:{{Main article|Battle of Palmdale}} Several [[Northrop F-89 Scorpion]]s attempted to shoot down a runaway [[Grumman F6F Hellcat|F6F-5K drone]], failing to bring it down with missile fire.<ref name="CNAS">{{cite web|url=http://415vva.homestead.com/Mil_Hist___Battle_of_Palmdale.pdf|title=Chronicles of Naval Aviation Steeljawscribe article|date=28 August 2007|accessdate=17 July 2016}}</ref> It crashed in a desert area.<ref name="CNAS"/> ;August 2013:A UAV filming events at the Virginia Bull Run in [[Dinwiddie County, Virginia]] crashed into the crowd, causing minor injuries.<ref name=atlantic-bull-run-crash>{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/08/drone-hits-spectators-watching-the-running-of-the-bulls-in-virginia/279040/|title=Drone Hits Spectators Watching the Running of the Bulls (in Virginia)|publisher=[[The Atlantic]]|last=Madrigal|first=Alexis|date=26 August 2013|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=wtvr-bull-run-crash>{{cite web|url=http://wtvr.com/2013/08/24/watch-drone-crashes-into-crowd-at-great-bull-run/|title=EXCLUSIVE VIDEO: Drone crashes into crowd at Great Bull Run|publisher=Wtvr.com|last1=Dutton|first1=Nick|last2=Bryan|first2=Alix|date=26 August 2013|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref>
;May 2014:Police were called to [[Hammonasset Beach State Park]] by Andrea Mears who claimed that [[Austin Haughwout]] had been filming people at a beach and that he had filmed people with his UAV and that he had assaulted her.<ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-beating>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/06/10/woman-faces-a-year-in-jail-for-beating-drone-operator-assault-caught-on-video/#368792f46290|title=Woman Faces A Year In Jail For Beating Drone Operator, Assault Caught On Video|first=Gregory S|last=McNeal|publisher=[[Forbes]]|date=10 June 2014|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-probation>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/07/14/woman-assaults-minor-over-a-drone-gets-mere-probation/#52547bfb188e|title=Woman Beats Up A Minor Over A Drone, Gets Mere Probation|first=Gregory S|last=McNeal|date=14 July 2014|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> The police prepared to arrest him, but he produced recordings from his UAV and mobile phone which showed that he hadn't been filming people and that Mears had assaulted him instead.<ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-beating/><ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-probation/> Mears was arrested and charged with assault in the 3rd degree and breach of peace in the 2nd degree.<ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-beating/> She was granted Accelerated Probation which erases her conviction from her record after two years.<ref name=forbes-haughwout-mears-probation/>
;June 2014:Ice hockey fans were celebrating a victory outside the [[Staples Center]] in 2014 when a UAV was seen flying over the crowd.<ref name=latimes-lapd-drone-staples-not-ours>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-drone-staples-not-lapd-20140616-story.html|title=LAPD: Drone above L.A. Kings fans outside Staples Center wasn't ours|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last1=Serna|first1=Joseph|last2=Chang|first2=Cindy|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=latimes-mystery-surrounds-drone>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-kings-game-drone-no-owner-20140616-story.html|title=Mystery surrounds drone that flew above L.A. Kings victory party|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last1=Serna|first1=Joseph|last2=Bennett|first2=Brian|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=forbes-video-shows-kings-fans-knocking-drone-out-of-sky>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/06/14/video-shows-kings-fans-knocking-drone-out-of-sky-did-it-belong-to-lapd/|title=Video Shows Kings Fans Knocking Drone Out Of Sky, Did It Belong To LAPD?|last=McNeal|first=Greg|date=14 June 2014|accessdate=17 June 2014|work=Forbes}}</ref> The crowd threw objects at the UAV, bringing it close enough to the ground for members of the crowd to grab it.<ref name=latimes-lapd-drone-staples-not-ours/><ref name=latimes-mystery-surrounds-drone/> Claims were made that the UAV belonged to the [[Los Angeles Police Department]], but the LAPD denied this.<ref name=latimes-lapd-drone-staples-not-ours/><ref name=latimes-mystery-surrounds-drone/>
;January 2015:A [[DJI (company)|DJI]] Phantom crashed in the grounds of the [[White House]].<ref name=nyt-white-house-drone-crash-described-as-a-us-workers-drunken-lark>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/28/us/white-house-drone.html?_r=0|title=White House Drone Crash Described as a U.S. Worker’s Drunken Lark|date=27 January 2015|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|last1=Shear|first1=Michael D.|last2=Schmidt|first2=Michael S.}}</ref> The operator had flown it while drunk and lost control of it.<ref name=nyt-white-house-drone-crash-described-as-a-us-workers-drunken-lark/>
;June 2015:A woman watching the [[Seattle]] [[Pride parade]] was hit by a falling UAV and knocked unconscious, suffering a [[concussion]].<ref name=seattle-times-woman-knocked-unconscious>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/crime/woman-knocked-unconscious-by-falling-drone-during-seattles-pride-parade/|title=Woman knocked unconscious by falling drone during Seattle’s Pride parade|publisher=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=29 June 2015|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=seattle-times-man-convicted-in-drone-crash/> She was standing near Fourth Avenue and Madison Street when the drone collided with a building, fell and struck her on the head.<ref name=seattle-times-woman-knocked-unconscious/> Her boyfriend caught her when she fell and an off-duty firefighter helped.<ref name=seattle-times-woman-knocked-unconscious/> Police investigated and the pilot came forward.<ref name=seattle-times-woman-knocked-unconscious/> In January 2017 Paul M. Skinner was found guilty of [[Endangerment|reckless endangerment]] by a six-person jury in a unanimous verdict before Judge Willie Gregory.<ref name=seattle-times-man-convicted-in-drone-crash>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/crime/man-convicted-in-drone-crash-that-injured-woman-during-seattles-pride-parade/|title=Man convicted in drone crash that injured woman during Seattle’s Pride Parade|last=Miletich|first=Steve|publisher=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=13 January 2017|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> It was the first time the Seattle Public Attorneys' office had convicted anyone of mishandling a drone in a public place.<ref name=seattle-times-man-convicted-in-drone-crash/> Such a conviction can carry a penalty of up to 364 days in jail and a $5000 fine.<ref name=seattle-times-man-convicted-in-drone-crash/> Mr. Skinner is scheduled to be sentenced in February 2017.<ref name=seattle-times-man-convicted-in-drone-crash/>
;July 2015:Firefighting aircraft were grounded for 26 minutes in Southern California because of fears of collisions with five UAVs that had been seen in the area.<ref name=abc-news-drones-delay>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/drones-delay-efforts-fight-california-wildfire/story?id=32534795|title=Drones Delay Efforts to Fight North Fire in Southern California|last1=Gutman|first1=Matt|last2=Gittleson|first2=Ben|last3=Candea|first3=Ben|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=18 July 2015|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> It was the fourth time in as many weeks that drones had hampered firefighters in Southern California.<ref name=abc-news-drones-delay/>
;August 2015:A police search in east Hollywood was interrupted by a UAV.<ref name=lat-drone-lapd-conviction>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-drone-pilot-lapd-conviction-20151118-story.html|title=Drone pilot is grounded and must forfeit device after interfering with LAPD search|first=Joseph|last=Serna|date=18 November 2015|accessdate=20 March 2016|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> Police had been searching for a man wanted for assault with a deadly weapon when a UAV flew near a [[Los Angeles Police Department]] helicopter.<ref name=lat-drone-lapd-conviction/> In November 2015 Martin Sheldon pleaded [[Nolo contendere|no contest]] to obstructing a police officer on 27 August 2015 when he flew his UAV near the helicopter.<ref name=lat-drone-lapd-conviction/> He had to surrender his UAV to police, complete 30 days of community labor and promise not to own or fly a UAV or other unmanned aircraft during his three years of probation.<ref name=lat-drone-lapd-conviction/>
;September 2015:A drone crashed into empty seating at the [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]] at [[Louis Armstrong Stadium]], causing no injuries according to the [[United States Tennis Association|USTA]].<ref name=cnn-drone-us-open>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/04/us/us-open-tennis-drone-arrest/index.html|title=Drone slams into seating area at U.S. Open; teacher arrested|date=5 September 2015|access-date=6 September 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|last=Talanova|first=Julia}}</ref> It happened during a match between [[Flavia Pennetta]] and [[Monica Niculescu]].<ref name=cnn-drone-us-open/> A teacher named Daniel Verley was arrested on charges of [[Endangerment|reckless endangerment]], reckless operation of a drone and operating a drone outside of a prescribed area in a New York city park.<ref name=cnn-drone-us-open/> He was released and ordered to attend court at a later date.<ref name=cnn-drone-us-open/> It is expressly forbidden to bring drones onto the grounds of the [[USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center|National Tennis Center]].<ref name=cnn-drone-us-open/> In October 2015 Daniel Verley was sentenced to community service, involving tutoring disenfranchised students.<ref name=wabc-sentenced>{{cite news|url=http://abc7ny.com/news/drone-crasher-gets-community-service-sentence/1013593/|title=U.S. Open drone 'crasher' sentenced to community service|publisher=[[WABC-TV]]|date=2 October 2015|accessdate=5 October 2015}}</ref> He had cooperated fully with the investigation.<ref name=wabc-sentenced/>
;October 2015:A drone collided with power lines in [[West Hollywood]], causing a [[power cut]] to 700 [[Southern California Edison]] customers.<ref name=lat-drone-power-west-hollywood>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-drone-power-west-hollywood-20151027-story.html|title=Drone knocks out power to hundreds of West Hollywood residents|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=Serna|first=Joseph|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref>
;December 2015:A man in [[Lockport (city), New York|Lockport, New York]] was charged with [[trespass]]ing after he allegedly flew a UAV near the Van De Mark chemical plant, which produces [[phosgene]] gas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city-region/lockport/man-charged-after-flying-drone-near-lockport-chemical-plant-20151205|title=Man charged after flying drone near Lockport chemical plant|publisher=[[The Buffalo News]]|date = 5 December 2015|accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref>
;December 2016:A drone flying near the [[Space Needle]] collided with the tower while pyrotechnicians were setting up fireworks for New Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/photo-video/video/watch-drone-crashes-into-space-needle-during-new-years-eve-fireworks-setup/|title=Watch: Drone crashes into Space Needle during New Year’s Eve fireworks setup|last=Lee|first=Jessica|publisher=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=11 January 2017|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>
;February 2017: A UAV flew into the window of a 27th storey apartment in [[Kips Bay, Manhattan]], breaking it while the occupant was at home.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abc7ny.com/news/drone-crashes-into-manhattan-apartment-shatters-window/1774826/|title=Drone crashes into Manhattan apartment, shatters window|publisher=[[WABC-TV]]|date=27 February 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/02/26/runaway-drone-crashes-through-kips-bay-apartment-window/|title=Runaway Drone Crashes Through Kips Bay Apartment Window|publisher=[[WCBS-TV]]|date=26 February 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref>
;May 2017: A UAV filming the Golden State Race Series in [[California]] collided with a tree, and spun out of control into a group of cyclists.<ref name=abc11-drone-cyclist-crash>{{cite news|url=http://abc11.com/news/crash-after-drone-flies-into-bike-race/1971533/|title=Crash after drone flies into bike race|publisher=ABC11.com|date=9 May 2017|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref> Part of the drone lodged in the front wheel of a cyclist, causing him to flip over his handlebars and suffer abrasions.<ref name=abc11-drone-cyclist-crash/> The drone operator reportedly offered to buy the cyclist a new front wheel and helmet.<ref name=abc11-drone-cyclist-crash/>
;May 2017: A track and field meeting at [[Trabuco Hills High School]] was targeted by a drone dropping water balloons on the event, though only one person was hit.<ref name=lat-drone-drops-water-ballons>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/highschool/varsity-times/la-sp-high-school-sports-drone-attack-htmlstory.html|title=Drone drops water balloons at Division 1 track prelims|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=13 May 2017|accessdate=14 May 2017|last=Ragan|first=Caleb}}</ref> The drone had been spotted the previous evening and the sports coach had sent people out to find the drone operators.<ref name=lat-drone-drops-water-ballons/> Police were notified the following morning.<ref name=lat-drone-drops-water-ballons/>
;May 2017: A [[GoPro]] Karma hit a seat at [[Petco Park]], narrowly missing fans during a match between the [[San Diego Padres]] and the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]].<ref name=gizmodo-petco-park>{{cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/watch-a-rogue-drone-crash-into-an-mlb-crowd-1795473669|title=Watch a Rogue Drone Crash Into the Crowd at an MLB Game|publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=12 June 2017|last=Estes|first=Adam Clark}}</ref><ref name=mashable-petco-park>{{cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2017/05/23/drone-baseball-game-crash/#7N5L75F1.sqK|title=Watch this drone nearly crash into fans at a baseball game|publisher=[[Mashable]]|last=Daileda|first=Colin|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> [[Major League Baseball]] said that UAVs are not allowed at baseball grounds.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/05/23/mlb-bans-drones-in-ballparks-after-one-nearly-takes-out-fans-at-padres-game/|title=MLB will ‘monitor the situation’ after drone nearly takes out fans at Padres game|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|last=Payne|first=Marissa|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref>
;September 2017: A 52-year-old woman saw a UAV flying outside the 42nd floor of a condominium tower in the 500 block of North [[Lake Shore Drive]] around 12:30pm on 9 September 2017.<ref name=cbs-chicago-man-charged-after-drone-hovers-outside-high-rise>{{cite news|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2017/09/12/man-charged-after-drone-hovers-outside-high-rise/|title=Man Charged After Drone Hovers Outside High Rise|publisher=[[CBS Chicago]]|date=12 September 2017|accessdate=15 September 2017}}</ref> According to police, it hovered for a long time near the building, without the consent of building management.<ref name=cbs-chicago-man-charged-after-drone-hovers-outside-high-rise/> Amit Kleiman, aged 31, attempted to retrieve the UAV from the third floor and was taken into custody.<ref name=cbs-chicago-man-charged-after-drone-hovers-outside-high-rise/> He was charged with one count each of criminal trespass, reckless conduct and breach of the peace.<ref name=cbs-chicago-man-charged-after-drone-hovers-outside-high-rise/>

[[File:Ultrasonic cleaner copy.jpg|thumb|300px|Ultrasonic cleaner showing the removable basket in place, and a closeup of the light and timer]]
'''Ultrasonic cleaning''' is a process that uses [[ultrasound]] (usually from 20–400 [[kHz]]) to agitate a fluid. The ultrasound can be used with just water, but use of a solvent appropriate for the item to be cleaned and the type of soiling present enhances the effect. Cleaning normally lasts between three and six minutes, but can also exceed 20 minutes, depending on the object to be cleaned.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dietz|first=Ellen Roberta and Raula Badavinac|title=Safety standards and infection control for dental hygienists|year=2002|publisher=Delmar Thomson Learning|location=Albany, NY|isbn=0766826600|pages=129|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VN6GjgCyn0IC&pg=PA129&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fz3wTqfoDoiQiAKw9JytDg&ved=0CIIBEOgBMAk4Cg#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false}}</ref>
Ultrasonic cleaners are used to clean many different types of objects, including [[jewellery|jewelry]], [[lens (optics)|lenses]] and other optical parts, [[watch]]es, [[dentistry|dental]] and [[surgical instrument]]s, [[tools]], [[coins]], [[fountain pens]], [[golf clubs]], [[fishing reels]], [[window blinds]], [[firearms]], car [[fuel injector]]s, musical instruments, [[gramophone record]]s''',''' industrial parts and electronic equipment. They are used in many jewelry workshops, [[watchmaker]]s' establishments, and electronic repair workshops.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ensminger|first=Dale|title=Ultrasonics: data, equations, and their practical uses, Volume 10|year=2009|publisher=CRC Press (Taylor & Francis Group)|location=Boca Raton, Florida|isbn=978-0-8247-5830-1|pages=328|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u2XlPFCbVPgC&pg=PA328&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fUPwTpOlNefhiALayIjIDg&ved=0CF4Q6AEwBDgo#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false}}</ref>
==History== The surface mechanisms of ultrasonic cleaning are well understood, with many works dedicated to this science since the first commercial ultrasonic cleaning equipment appeared in the 1950s, and came into use as relatively inexpensive home appliances in about 1970.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wahl|first=Paul|title=Put Sound Waves to Work in Your Shop|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6QAAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA94&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fUPwTpOlNefhiALayIjIDg&ved=0CFUQ6AEwAjgo#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=Popular Science|date=March 1970}}</ref> Ultrasonic cleaning has been used industrially for decades, particularly to clean small intricate parts, and to accelerate surface treatment processes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Phillion|first=R.|date=June 2011|title=The Application of Industrial Scale Ultrasonic Cleaning to Heat Exchangers|url=http://www.heatexchanger-fouling.com/papers/papers2011/48_Kieser_F.pdf|journal=Heat Exchanger Fouling and Cleaning|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==Process characteristics== Ultrasonic cleaning uses [[cavitation]] bubbles induced by high frequency pressure (sound) waves to agitate a liquid. The agitation produces high forces on contaminants adhering to substrates like metals, plastics, glass, rubber, and ceramics. This action also penetrates [[blind hole]]s, cracks, and recesses. The intention is to thoroughly remove all traces of contamination tightly adhering or embedded onto solid surfaces. [[Water]] or [[solvent]]s can be used, depending on the type of contamination and the workpiece. Contaminants can include dust, dirt, oil, pigments, rust, grease, algae, fungus, bacteria, lime scale, polishing compounds, flux agents, fingerprints, soot wax and mold release agents, biological soil like blood, and so on. Ultrasonic cleaning can be used for a wide range of workpiece shapes, sizes and materials, and may not require the part to be disassembled prior to cleaning.<ref name=Todd>Robert H. Todd, Dell K. Allen, and Leo Alting; ''Manufacturing Processes Reference Guide''</ref>
Objects must not be allowed to rest on the bottom of the device during the cleaning process, because that will prevent [[cavitation]] from taking place on the part of the object not in contact with solvent.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ensminger|first=Dale|title=Ultrasonics: data, equations, and their practical uses, Volume 10|year=2009|publisher=CRC Press (Taylor & Francis Group)|location=Boca Raton, Florida|isbn=978-0-8247-5830-1|pages=328–358|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u2XlPFCbVPgC&pg=PA328&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fUPwTpOlNefhiALayIjIDg&ved=0CF4Q6AEwBDgo#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false}}</ref>
==Design and operating principle==
In an ultrasonic cleaner, the object to be cleaned is placed in a chamber containing a suitable solution (in an aqueous or organic solvent, depending on the application). In aqueous cleaners, [[surfactant]]s (e.g., laundry detergent) are often added to permit dissolution of non-polar compounds such as oils and greases. An ultrasound generating [[transducer]] built into the chamber, or lowered into the fluid, produces ultrasonic waves in the fluid by changing size in concert with an electrical signal oscillating at ultrasonic frequency. This creates compression waves in the liquid of the tank which 'tear' the liquid apart, leaving behind many millions of microscopic 'voids'/'partial vacuum bubbles' (cavitation). These bubbles collapse with enormous energy; temperatures and pressures on the order of 5,000 K and 135 MPa are achieved;<ref name=Henglein>{{cite journal|last1=Henglein|first1=A.|last2=Gutierrez|first2=M.|year=1993|title=Sonochemistry and sonoluminescence: Effects of external pressure|journal=J. Phys. Chem.|volume=97|pages=158–162.}}</ref><ref name=Azar>{{cite web|last1=Azar|first1=Lawrence|date=February 2009|title=Cavitation in ultrasonic cleaning and cell disruption|publisher=Controlled Environments|url=http://www.absotecthailand.com/Cavitation.pdf}}</ref> however, they are so small that they do no more than clean and remove surface dirt and contaminants. The higher the frequency, the smaller the nodes between the cavitation points, which allows for cleaning of more intricate detail.
[[File:Resize 2 of transducer comparison.jpg|frame|right|Ultrasonic transducers showing ~20 kHz and ~40 kHz stacks. The active elements (near the top) are two rings of [[lead zirconate titanate]], which are bolted to an aluminium coupling horn.]]
Transducers are usually [[Piezoelectricity|piezoelectric]] (e.g. made with [[lead zirconate titanate]] (PZT), [[barium titanate]], etc.), but are sometimes [[Magnetostriction|magnetostrictive]]. The often harsh chemicals used as cleaners in many industries are not needed, or used in much lower concentrations, with ultrasonic agitation. Ultrasonics are used for industrial cleaning, and also used in many medical and dental techniques and industrial processes.
==Cleaning solution==
Ultrasonic activity (cavitation) helps the solution to do its job; plain water would not normally be effective. The cleaning solution contains ingredients designed to make ultrasonic cleaning more effective. For example, reduction of [[surface tension]] increases cavitation levels, so the solution contains a good wetting agent ([[surfactant]]). Aqueous cleaning solutions contain detergents, wetting agents and other components, and have a large influence on the cleaning process. Correct composition of the solution is very dependent upon the item cleaned. Solutions are mostly used warm, at about {{convert|50|-|65|C|F}}, however, in medical applications it is generally accepted that cleaning should be at temperatures below {{convert|45|C}} to prevent protein coagulation.
Water-based solutions are more limited in their ability to remove contaminants by chemical action alone than solvent solutions; e.g. for delicate parts covered with thick grease. The effort required to design an effective aqueous-cleaning system for a particular purpose is much greater than for a solvent system.
Some machines (which are not unduly large) are integrated with [[vapour degreasing]] machines using hydrocarbon cleaning fluids: Three tanks are used in a cascade. The lower tank containing dirty fluid is heated causing the fluid to evaporate. At the top of the machine there is a refrigeration coil. Fluid condenses on the coil and falls into the upper tank. The upper tank eventually overflows and clean fluid runs into the work tank where the cleaning takes place. Purchase price is higher than simpler machines, but such machines are economical in the long run. The same fluid can be reused many times, minimising wastage and pollution.
==Uses== Most hard, non-absorbent materials (metals, plastics, etc.) not chemically attacked by the cleaning fluid are suitable for ultrasonic cleaning. Ideal materials for ultrasonic cleaning include small electronic parts, cables, rods, wires and detailed items, as well as objects made of glass, plastic, aluminium or ceramic.<ref>{{cite book|last=Williams|first=Douglas|title=Guide to Cleaner Technologies: Cleaning and Degreasing Process Changes|year=1994|publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency|location=Washington DC|pages=19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hVeitHI6pM4C&pg=PA18&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Tz3wTsHPNuWaiAKp65ScDg&ved=0CFgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false}}</ref>
Ultrasonic cleaning does not sterilize the objects being cleaned, because spores and viruses will remain on the objects after cleaning. In medical applications, sterilization normally follows ultrasonic cleaning as a separate step.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simmers|first=Louise, and Karen Simmers-Nartker, Sharon Simmers-Kobelak|title=Diversified Health Occupations: Seventh Edition|year=2009|publisher=Delmar Cengage Learning Academic Resource Center|location=Clifton Park, NY|isbn=978-1-4180-3021-6|pages=381|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nz0bpa6oem8C&pg=PA381&dq=ultrasonic+cleaning&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fz3wTqfoDoiQiAKw9JytDg&ved=0CFUQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=ultrasonic%20cleaning&f=false}}</ref>
Industrial ultrasonic cleaners are used in the automotive, sporting, printing, marine, medical, pharmaceutical, electroplating, disk drive components, engineering and weapons industries.
Ultrasonic cleaning is used to remove contamination from industrial process equipment such as pipes and heat exchangers.
==Limitations== Ultrasonic cleaning is used widely to remove flux residue from soldered circuit boards. However, some electronic components, notably [[MEMS]] devices such as [[Vibrating structure gyroscope#MEMS gyroscopes|gyroscopes]], [[accelerometer]]s and [[microphones]] can become damaged or destroyed by the high intensity vibrations they are subjected to during cleaning. Piezoelectric [[Buzzer#Piezoelectric|buzzers]] can work in reverse and produce voltage, which may pose a danger to their drive circuits.
== Safety ==
It is recommended to avoid using flammable cleaning solutions because ultrasonic cleaners increase temperature even when not equipped with a heater. When the unit is running, inserting your hand into the solution could cause burning due to the temperature; discomfort and skin irritation can also occur.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nist.gov/sites/default/files/documents/ncnr/UltrasonicCleaner_Branson_1510.pdf|title=Ultrasonic Cleaner Operator's Manual|publisher=Branson|access-date=November 2, 2018}}</ref>

'''Wake-on-Ring''' ('''WOR'''), sometimes referred to as Wake-on-Modem (WOM), is a specification that allows supported computers and devices to "wake up" or turn on from a sleeping, [[Hibernate (OS feature) | hibernating]] or "soft off" state (e.g. [[Advanced Configuration and Power Interface | ACPI]] state G1 or G2), and begin operation.
The basic premise is that a special [[Signalling (telecommunications)|signal]] is sent over phone lines to the computer through its [[dial-up modem]], telling it to fully power-on and begin operation. Common uses were [[archive]] [[database]]s and [[Bulletin board system|BBSes]], although hobbyist use was significant.
[[Fax]] machines use a similar system, in which they are mostly idle until receiving an incoming fax signal, which spurs operation.
This style of [[remote operation]] has mostly been supplanted by [[Wake-on-LAN]], which is newer but works in much the same way.
